p: Since 2015, various studies have been conducted, such as reviews and case reports with contradictory results on important points. According to Ellington et al. in 2016, the probability of microcephaly in infants was about 1% to 13%, with limited data for the second and third trimesters [ 6]. However, other researchers, e.g., Alvarado 2017, claim that the relationship of the microcephaly and Zika virus is in doubt and perhaps there is some connection, but it is not yet clarified [ 7]. Other investigations show a stronger correlation between Zika virus infections and congenital malformations and even make reference to the presence of endometrial fetal death [ 8, 9]. In light of the findings of an association between Zika virus and central nervous system (CNS) abnormalities, recent studies have shown a strong relation but only the exposed infants with microcephaly or other malformations are more likely to have low cognitive development [ 10].
